Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 10:42PM unique wrote: Hi Girls, The Club sounds great! I sort of feel like I'm in one already, over on the "Wii Exercise" forum. We are comparing our Wii FIT scores over there. I am not allowed to lose weight yet but am eating better - I never ate badly - but am focusing on getting more fruits and veggies and lots more water. Exercising really does feel great! Altho last week my son was sick I did not feel real good either, kind of tired, and as my onc says, it's impossible to sort out what is what sometimes. I was a bit dizzy on Tuesday and wondered about that, but it's not radiation because I had a dizzy thing - my GP and I thought it was probably inner ear. One half, love the avatar - about 10 years ago I bought a pile of those stamps, not realizing until I got home that they were VERY expensive. Well I gave to a good cause LOL! Donna, I'm sorry your oncs aren't helping you understand things more. I believe the DCIS is usually the smallest, earliest cancer to have, so please feel relieved that you are most likely in a very good situation! My Mom had this also and she had the lumpectomy and rads. Her surgeon told her it is like a pre-cancer. Check it out but you may be happy to know that you are in a better position than many of us! Usually they don't want to do a mastectomy unless there's a good reason, for example, I had a largeish tumor of 4+cm that was diffuse, none of the scans could show exactly where it ended. That's why I had the mast, I definitely did not want to have them not get good margins and have to do over! Studies have shown that lumpectomy plus radiation is JUST AS EFFECTIVE as mastectomy in many cases. I plan to go on an AI after rads are over, and one of us or both of us (my Mom and me) are getting tested for BRCA genes, on behalf of my sister, who is the gal who didn't have a problem yet. Well she had a biopsy but it was "just" calcification and they want to keep an eye on it. She is kind of annoyed by this LOL! Not half as annoyed as I was when I had a cancer diagnosis!!! Maybe keep trying oncologists until you find one you like ... if your insurance permits ... I saw four oncologists but the first one I saw was a doll - I just wanted to double check what he was telling me, and he was right on. Plus he was kind, listened well, has a good perspective, was angry on my behalf about what is not yet known (he thinks they should know more by now!!!), etc. I adore him.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 02:00PM - edited Mar 3, 2009 02:00PM by unique I'm worrying and worrying this week. First I had to cancel my PT appt for Monday and have to wait a whole other week to see her. Then today rads took a LONG time, about an hour or longer, because they just could not get me in the right position. They always want my torso to go left and my shoulder to go right. Just not a very happening thing. Anyway, I can be fairly comfortable with the wee back pillow and neck pillow, but after all the realignment of me the neck pillow was out of wack and the arm was hurting. There's an arm holder where you put it so it's up and over your head. It tends to go to sleep in the "cuff" part on the best of days and on the worst it hurts like hell. Now I have a thought it will cause lymphedema in that arm. I thought about Guantanamo prisoners being in positions for long periods of time and have sympathy about that, because it hurts like hell! It's a metal table and it's hard. What are you all lying on? What holds your arm? Does it cause discomfort, the way you are lying? My treatments take a lot longer than I thought they would, too - the shortest are about 25 minutes because I have 4 fields to zap. Kfinnigan - your docs are sort of right, sometimes you can get lymphedema no matter what. But there ARE exercises you can do to decrease your chance of getting it. I got my referral from my doctor but then went online to www.lymphnet.org/resourceGuide... to cross-check. You want a LANA certified therapist. Just enter your zip code.

Moore, where the bathroom is on the back left of the store. Anyway, I ran for it in the Michael's and it wasn't there! So I ran to the other end of the store, and I could tell ... sigh ... I hadn't made it. Once I got in there and took a look - ew! This episode is directly responsible for me carrying extra underwear and a baggie everywhere I go nowadays. But that time I was stymied. I cleaned myself up with wipes but wondered how to get my dirty underwear home. Then it struck me! Wash the solid stuff out! But not in the sink, I would never do that to the next person. So I held the underwear firmly and dipped the dirty parts in the commode, and hit the flush. I figured once I got home I could soak things in bleach, etc. get them really clean. But I let loose of them! And there, swirling round and round in the toilet bowl, a pair of grandma undies! I held my breath, would they go down? Would they get stuck? Would there be an overflow? Could I ever show my face in the Michael's again? They went down. Of course, I went right home, and I had to go without any underwear beneath my jeans. :@* Are you guys surprised I'm not too nonplussed by minor indignities like being bare for radiation?

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2009 05:49PM unique wrote: Hi galz! Had my second planning session today and I start rads tomorrow!!! I didn't even get my lymphedema PT referral yet, I had wanted to see that person before I started. How important is this??? I have to say, I did not like this session at all! The position I was in was most uncomfortable and I had to hold it for nearly an hour. Not a happy camper. First the neck and then the left arm got painful and then numb. Also the scalp where the donut thingy was pressing into my head. They kept saying they almost done. I stuck with it and am proud of myself. I do not like pain! The actual rad sessions should be short, so even if they wrap me into a pretzel shape it shouldn't matter. I'm thinking today was the hard part. They did let me have a little pillow under my low back so at least that didn't hurt like last time. Grumbled a bit but I am swaybacked so there's a space when I lie down where my spine curves, and that hurts if no support. I showed her it made no difference pillow or no pillow, so she let me have it!!! And I noticed, I totally didn't see this last time, they have the most beautiful lit screens of flowers and she played music, one of my favs, Simon and Garfunkel, the Bridge over Troubled Waters album, made me think of being in college LOL. I also did the color exercise. I thought of things that are yellow. Here is part of my list: the sun, daffodils, egg yolks, lemons, squash, smiley faces (see above), Pikachu, Spongebob, Sprint phones, galoshes (the old fashioned ones), chicks, duck bills, chicken feet, yellow crayons, yellow markers, hilighters, flame, school busses, my teeth (too much coffee), tulips, pancake batter, my son's hair, manila folders ... and so on. pottergal - did I say the wii fit was great? Yeah, it's very interesting, keeps the boredom at bay. It seems to start you out on an easy regimen, but I've gotten to advanced step and it is a real workout! They keep adding things too and I feel I'm not ready for the new stuff, I am still happy with the old stuff, except for the advanced step and the new yoga techniques. I am on my second week and I can do an hour every day, the time just whizzes by. You can also compete against yourself or other players in your family, and that can be fun! I want to beat my kid on the ski slope, I almost got there today. You can keep on doing one thing or vary your routine, it's totally up to you. The only drawback with some of the things is that if you want to repeat the routine, you have to hit the go again button and wade through some of the explanation each time. I just keep doing whatever the exercise is while this is going on. It's only a couple of seconds though, hardly worth complaining about. Once you've done the demo for each exercise they don't repeat that. It also keeps track of your total exercise time and doesn't count the menu wading as part of it. So you know how much time you've actually been in motion. I think it's great, I've never been faithful to an exercise program before now, I always get bored.

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 11:26PM unique wrote: Fammy ~ So sorry you had all that trouble! Did you take Dexamethasone the day before and then for two days? Did they give you Aloxi in your IV? Did they give you a script for Ativan with instructions to take that for nausea first, then to go to Compazine or Zofran? You can also take Emmends but it's very expensive. My tips for chemo success are as much water as you can drink - just tote a water bottle around with you everywhere and sip all the time. I am getting in about 96 oz and that helps with the bone pain and everything else. Tylenol or whatever analgesic they tell you to take. Caffeine if you can get it down, I do coffee and have not had trouble with nausea yet. Mountain Dew might be good if Pepsi gives you trouble. Caffeine also helps with constipation, Miralax also. Immodium for diarrhea. If you can drink it, cranberry juice will forstall a urine infection, yoghurt with live yeast cultures will help with vaginal infections. I am really being careful going out, except for eating at restaurants, but only decent ones I know and trust, and only hot food, no salads. I am washing my hands all the time, they're definitely getting dried out but that's better than ending up in the hospital. None of these things might be right for you, I'm just throwing them all out there in case there's one that makes it better next time. I did TX#2 today, and I'm achy and full of hot flashes and chills, but otherwise okay. My neck hurts.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2008 11:46PM unique wrote: Deb ~ How about you stay with us here and ALSO start a November chemo thread. Although - I have two more treatments to go so I'll be here in November and so will many of us. I am actually on two boards here, one for my specific type of chemo, TC, and also here. Both have been tremendously helpful, you have no idea!!!!!!!!! There's a Tip list here somewhere, I've forgotten where it is tho, I can send it to you privately if you like.  Here are Anne's Chemo Tips ~ Good luck with the lumpectomy! The only surprise I had was the "galloping horses" in my pelvis and thighs for about 24 hours. It wasn't really that painful, just unnerving. Tylenol put it to sleep, but whatever analgesic should be an 8-hour version because all night every 4 hours once the Tylenol would wear off the gallops would start up again. 1. I think much of the key to reducing side effects is HUGE amounts of water. Helps to flush all the poisons out. My onc said 48 oz a day but I am doing twice that now. 2. Keep them bowels moving, and be ready for either constipation or diarrhea. I had constipation the first week, but no stoppage, just a feeling of pressure and then had to huff and puff a little. Out came marbles, which is not my usual! Today I had some loose ones. Coffee with caffeine is good to start the bowels in the morning, if it doesn't disturb your stomach. Mine has been fine so far. 3. Yoghurt with live cultures and cranberry juice to ward off yeast infections and bladder infections. I felt like one of either might be coming on over the last couple days but things seem fine today. 4. Lots of salt water and/or baking soda gargling. I also do a nose rinse with warm salt water most mornings to clear out my post nasal drip. This also helps with scratchy/sore throat and that fuzzy tongue thing. 5. All fruit popsicles like Edy's or Tropicana to add fluids, counteract that chemical taste in the mouth. Lots of fruit juice, soup broth, aromatic teas (Throat Coat by Yogi Tea feels oh so good going down, it has licorice in it which soothes the throat). 6. Hot sweats or chills plus that feverish feeling - either a cold pack from the freezer OR a hot herb pack which is squirted with a little water and then heated up for two minutes in the microwave. I have lots of these latter due to my history with sinus headaches and migraines. They do a charm with muscle aches, just zap a few and take them to bed with you and the warmth is just so soothing. I have lived with my son's little terry Piggy ice pack when cold seems to be what I need, I feel like I'm burning up or something. Pack of peas does the same. 7. Not sleeping - take a Benadryl, it will knock you right out! Good night to you, too!

My hair started to fall out around Day 14 - it did prickle quite a bit for about a week before that. It hasn't fallen all the way out but it is VERY thin. About that menopause - after I was ALL DONE I felt just great!!! You may really get a second wind. I was a wreck from 2002 through 2005 pretty much, woke up every night in a sweat, couldn't get back to sleep, anxious, achy, tired, headaches. I did go on Paxil in 2004 and the night sweats went away. So don't borrow trouble and look forwards to a new era in your life, ok? Kathi - I had pulsating and my onc also thought it was dehydration. Glad they were able to fix you up there! It can also be the Neulasta. TNT - I was real worried after the whole thing with my husband that I would just be a wreck when the next shoe dropped. And as I was telling Lynn, I was a wreck most of the time after my husband died, went thru all those emotions, grief, feeling like half a person, anxious about everything. But, as it turns out, I've learned something from it all, and I can feel it, a sense of peace about the future, no matter what happens, altho I'll be honest sometimes I feel afraid too, but I also feel an inner strength.

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2008 09:59AM unique wrote: I am thinking so much about Cheryl, hoping it will go much better than she was worrying. Maybe in a day or two she'll come in here and let us know and hopefully it was okay. None of this is great, but survivable at least I hope. I have had trouble with overwhelming panic and I have learned to take my little pills (Ativan sometimes, Klonopin sometimes) when I really need them, that is if I am pacing and hyperventilating. I use prayer, music, friends, positive thoughts etc. and you never know what is going to help your panic, it could be any one of these OR a little pill. Use the tools you have I say! I have had help with my panic, generally speaking am doing fine now since I started treatment, only need a part of a pill every now and then, haven't needed anything for weeks now ... I am hoping the Emends and Aloxi and Decadron make her SE's tolerable. Now back to makeup and hair!!! Yay!!! TNT, just play with the makeup, you'll get the knack. I got some eyeliner but I'll tell you it was a failure, I'm back to just playing up my eyes a tad with some eye shadow. I'm tossing some of it now because it was the wrong color, and getting some new in the right color now. I didn't wear much makeup for the last 10 years because (strutting) I looked pretty good even without it, would just do it when a work event or something. I finally got lipstick in the right color but it's a little irritating on my lips this week, that wrong color is very moisturizing LOL! Have fun with it. Benefits and Your Public Persona ~ I think this is a topic all on its own. Somehow it can feel strange how people react to your cancer diagnosis and treatment. Their take on it is of course going to be different than your reality. I try to just accept whatever love and good feelings come my way even if it doesn't quite fit. I have been trained though, have had a number of upsets, health and otherwise, with my hubby and myself so have been here, done this, and wear that T-shirt because what else ya gonna do! The only caveat with this would be on occasion the Well drive the Sick crazy with well-intentioned projects - the Benefit should not put you out, you should not exert extra energy about it. You need to heal! I remember with my sweetie his relatives had us make a trip to visit them from Chicago to Pennsylvania/New York and that is just STOOPID. He wanted to go anyway. But the Sick do not visit the Well, it is supposed to be the other way around!!! Crazy family dynamics. So stand firm if folks' helps aren't really helpful, let them know what you need and don't budge. Do you need some extra money? Some of us are way shorted on medical insurance so definitely could use a bit of a help here, so let em throw the Benefit and be well and happy, okay? I think it definitely helps to let folks do whatever they are moved to do, it is good for them as well as for us. We are *ALL* gonna have times in our life when we need help and when we have the opportunity to help others. So they will feel better if they are part of the Helping Thing, it's just good all around.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2008 08:32PM unique wrote: Kristi - I have no idea why I am so up, as you say. Actually since 2004 I was clinically depressed, but after going on Paxil this got better. I was worried I was not strong enough for the rest of my life, felt very fragile, would freak out driving distances. Since my periods stopped though I feel like a new woman. Was it all menopause? It is hard to say because my husband died in 2000, then we had 9/11 which freaked most of us out, me too, and politically speaking it has been a roller coaster to say the least. I was strong while my husband was ill. Then I sort of fell apart? Was it PSTD and it resolved? I was really scared when I got the diagnosis, just was pacing, hyperventilating, praying, talking to friends, singing songs in the shower, running around my house, finally I settled down once all my tests came back and I was able to say, well, this part is not so bad. I think the worst moment for me was after my operation and my surgeon said I did have micromets in 2 of my nodes. I just had to sob for about 10 minutes. Then I accepted that and went on. Since then, I've been fine. Is it Adrenalin? Is it a new mind set from having this? I used to fret how my savings would last through my "retirement" - you know around 75 when I am too sick to work, how I would afford my medications for arthritis or whatnot, would I have to suffer a lot of pain? and I'll tell you I am not worrying about that at all any more!!! If I live that long it will have to take care of itself!!! I am going to be happy RIGHT NOW for pete's sake. Does this make any sense? I may have more trouble once my treatment is over, I'll have less adrenalin going on, more time to think worrisome thoughts, but I hope I don't, I just focus on BEING HAPPY for however long I have on the planet. The only other thing I can think of is Vitamin D. I get enough of that now, from about 1985 to last year I kept out of the sun, and I mean totally (so as not to get skin cancer). They now think Vitamin D is important for lots of things. Could my good mood be partly that I get enough Vitamin D? I also take a multi that gives me lots of B too. Not too much, my onc passed on my vits.  Does anyone else wonder why they are taking it all well? Or why they're not? I'm not sure there are any good answers though. P.S.: The only two things that really stopped the panic were 1. shopping at Target and 2. Half a Klonopin. Part of it may be the Klonopin works for me if I've prayed, ran, meditated, vented, shopped and none of those has helped. It takes the panic and makes it disappear.

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 04:49PM unique wrote: Karen ~ everybody is different, but ask your onco or nurse about avoiding all the nausea next round. Things to ask about: Dexamethasone the day before and for a couple days after, Aloxi in your IV, Ativan for nausea after, then Compazine if that doesn't work, then Zofran if that doesn't work OR since you had so much trouble if your insurance will pay for it the amazing miraculous Emend which is $400 for the 3 doses I kid you not. I got it all but didn't need it - I have had other issues. It is crazy - I had aches and pains my 1st round and this round it's none of that but instead heartburn and brain fog. I've been weepy for the last three days and everyone on here knows I'm a cheerful person by nature. I'm just so tired of losing everything and being disoriented. Whatever it is, it usually lasts just a couple of days and then you feel better. Think of that and stay strong! fivekids, have fun with your hats. I sure have!

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2008 05:53PM unique wrote: Hi gals ~ doing okay, finished TC#4 on Wednesday, feeling gingky today but not too bad. Picked up some books at the onc office - they have a whole bookshelf of mysteries and bodice rippers that I guess people have donated. I did pick up one that was great about breast cancer - "After Breast Cancer" by Musa Mayer. I've been wondering about checkups after my treatment is over (maybe I'm done, my onc wants me to double check with a rad onc about rads because the treatment standards are changing, they are starting to put more rads back) and my surgeon didn't recommend a whole lot of testing, which disturbed me. This book kind of gave me a different perspective about testing after, because I guess most of them don't tell you much but just put you in for a lot of other tests and upset, and it's really symptoms that will tell us if we are having a new problem. This made some sense to me. I am seeing an expert in December and will ask him too about tests he thinks are good to do. I hope we are all done with breast cancer after our chemo and rads!!! We have to have confidence that we will be okay for a long, long time, and there's no reason to not be confidence in the light of all the new things coming along all the time.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 10:20AM unique wrote: Hi, Linda ~ Yes, you can do chemo!!! You will find the chemo will make you lighten up some, but for the most part your retirement can continue to blossom. Think a couple days every 3 weeks or so that you are resting, drinking lots of fluids, eating popsicles and crashing on the couch with a good book. Part time sounds great, it's what I do, and I work when I feel like it and catch up on my reading when I don't. Acronyms, let's see ~ ILC and IDC are infiltrating lobular and ductal carcinomas. Stage is how hey evaluate early detection or not. Stages 0, 1, and 2 are considered early. Grade is how aggressive. You will see our gals fighting some of these and they are still kicking cancer butt. ER/PR and HER are receptors. ER is estrogen receptor positive, PR is progesterone I think, I forgot what HER is. You really get a different style treatment if you are ER/PR negative and there's a chemo, Herceptin, that really works well on HER+.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2008 01:36PM unique wrote: Hi, Unique here ~ I *think* the cold is better. Today was the first day I didn't have a rush of stuff trying to get out of my lungs and head on first getting up, leading to a coughing fest of about 20 minutes before it died down. I swear I've been spending most of my waking time productively coughing mucus for the last week. But the downside is that the low fever came back last night. I felt really exhausted and took a little nap from 5-7 pm then got up to feed my son and felt yukky - achy and feverish and there it was at 99.6 again. So I don't know. But while stuff stayed put first thing this morning about an hour and a half after I got up I had to honk up a whole lot of glue, so is it the same thing? My son has a low fever and he is home today as well. I'm sorry to be absent from posting but I've been trying to catch up with stuff while I was down for the count and that is hard! Spent an hour or so on the phone checking that all the slides and films at three different places will be there next week when I go to pick them up. UPenn called to say they hadn't gotten anything, they were expecting my slides to go by mail, which I said, looking at my notes, they had told me to bring on foot. I wouldn't want my precious slides to go by mail, what if they get lost!!! (They did lose a critical MRI of my husband's in transit and neither hospital had another copy, luckily I had one in my big MRI bag, so I've been there done that and learned the lessons.) So I've been a busy little bee in spite of my cold but I am still horribly behind. I did pay my medical bills (checked the bank balance, wrote checks, licked stamps, gave to parents to mail Wed. nite). I can sleep for the rest of the day along with my kid if I want, all I have to do is check on the car to see if the body shop got the parts yet. I may cave and get a loaner next week. I just kinda dread having to go pick it up and so forth because the only thing I really have to drive for is taking my kid to his class Wed. nite. Everything else - grocery, etc. is within walking distance altho I haven't wanted to walk because it's cold and rainy and when I go out it makes things run and inspires coughing fits (with a need to spit mucus which I can't do while I'm out). If the coughing doesn't get better, I'll go back for another antibiotic or something. QUESTIONS: When after chemo can we start taking vitamin C again? I blame the length of the cold partly on my lack of C. I used to take 1500 mg a day and did pretty well, but then stopped it and now only get 60mg in my multi-vitamin.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 09:45AM unique wrote: Kristi ~ I am SO SORRY you are having so much trouble. I am thinking Vicodin, that is Tylenol plus Codeine, but just because I have taken it from time to time. But definitely ask you onc for something stronger. I used Ativan for sleeping, but many of us take it also for nausea and to relax a little. They like me to take it before I come in for infusion. One thing that might be aggravating your sleeping - Decadron tends to make you AWAKE. But if you're feeling this sick that by itself might be making you sooooooo anxious. I find my mental state is very affected by how I feel physically. I imagine it is because all my serotonin is sucked up by the pain (Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that works with both mood and pain) and then I'm in more pain and also more upset. So there you have it. Now, my first TX was the worst and they have all been better from there out except as Gilda Radner would say "it's always something" - today I am having bruises on my inner arm and therefore another trip in to town to see the onc. I did have other plans!!! Other thing - maybe your onc will decide the TAC is too hard and do AC+T instead, that would be AC every two weeks and then when that is done just T every two weeks. My onc said TAC is very tough, he finds people tolerate the AC+T better. Or lower your dose a tad. There are lots of ways to help you tolerate your treatment better. We all want to gut it out so we get the Most Cancer Killing Drugs, but if you can't get through the treatment what good is it? Right????????

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2008 09:40PM unique wrote: Kathi ~ Don't lose heart about the A. It's a good chemo but the T&C are also very good. There's a little argument in the onco community about whether to do T&A&C or to do just the T&C. The MUGA is a heart scan, the Adriamycin can damage the heart, and if you failed it, look on the bright side and you will lose the 1% change of a heart problem. Guess you already have something there that worries them about the heart. So one less thing in my humble opinion. The Adriamycin has been successful for many years but the oncs are dying to find something with fewer possible heart effects down the road. They only give folks a certain dose they hope is safe. The Taxotere/Cytoxan combo is newer but there's a study that shows T&C is better than A&C, and a study just starting that pits T&A&C against T&C to see which does better. We won't know for at least 10 years, but some oncs are staying with the tried and true while others are jumping off to try the new thing. I got several second opinions so some oncs wanted to do T, A and C and others wanted to do just T & C. I decided to do just the T & C. We won't know for a number of years who is right, and which is better, but both are good. Is this more than you ever wanted to know?  There is a TC list on here if you are interested.

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2008 10:13PM unique wrote: Hi all ~ I got my #3 infusion today and it went like a charm. My WBCs are up, my RBCs a tad down but my onc is pleased just a little. No neuropathy or other problems. Joy, I had chemo brain really badly last week and it got me very upset but this week it has been fine. I misplaced important things and couldn't find nouns. The first made me very cranky, the latter I was able to joke about. I'd had a cold but it was better yesterday, mostly blowing, loose coughing up and draining. Today I barely noticed it at all. My son's cold has gotten worse though, tonight has a fever with 100. Not high for a kid but he will be off school tomorrow. I will have to take him to my Neulasta shot but maybe make him sit in the hall. The gal next to me in the chemo room is doing AC+T and I'll tell you, that Adriamycin is red!!! She had a tiny little aggressive tumor in her breast but a huge tumor in her lymph nodes. She found her breast cancer because she was having wierd brain problems, they thought she had a brain tumor, a lymphoma, anything but breast cancer. Once the operation was over, all her brain symptoms went away. Evidently poisons from the tumor. That is different and amazing. I guess we all have a different journey. The man next to me looked kind of dejected. I tried to talk to him but he was a one word dude. He was a lung cancer patient, had part of his lung removed and getting chemo for that. Fammy, Lori, and Cheryl also went today and I am wondering how you all are doing? I know it doesn't usually hit for a day or two, but I'm just pooped from spending half a day in a chair getting the drugs. Heh.
